Feature: Is there weight-sensitive suprasegmental prominence, suprasegmental prominence can be loudness, duration, pitch, i.e. stress or tone phenomena?
Are there definite or specific articles?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Form same as demonstratives, Form same as pronoun, Definiteness marking is done by an element with another function such as numeral classifiers, Definiteness marking is very restricted

Feature: Is an indefinite NP obligatorily accompanied by an indefinite (or non-specific) article?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, It exists but it is not obligatory, Same as numeral 'one'

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The definite article is prenominal, The indefinite article is prenominal, The definite article is a prefix, The indefinite article is a prefix

Feature: Are there postnominal articles?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The definite article is postnominal, The indefinite article is postnominal, The definite article is a suffix, The indefinite article is a suffix

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Mostly numeral-noun with a few exceptions, Mostly noun-numeral with a few exceptions, Either order occurs with any numeral

Feature: What is the order of demonstrative and noun in the NP?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Different demonstratives take different orders, There is free variation, Demonstrative construction has a form both before and after the noun, Demonstrative are treated as suffixes, Demonstrative are treated as prefixes

Feature: Are there 'discontinuous noun phrases'?
Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John went to market with Mary')?
Comment: word order is different but for 'and' and 'with' the same word is used: nora (the verb -ora 'being with' taking default agreement)

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: pronouns and person affixes

Feature: Is there a minimal-augmented system?
Is there a gender distinction in 3rd person pronouns (or demonstratives, if no 3rd person pronouns)?
Is there a dual (or unit augmented) in addition to a plural (or augmented) number category in pronouns?
Are 1st and 2nd persons conflated in any context?
Comment: 1PL.EX and 2PL in agreement prefixes (for suffixes also in Singular)
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Same pronoun form covering both first and second person in some context, Person is marked on the verb and there is a context where first and second person are the same

Feature: Are 2nd and 3rd persons conflated in non-singular numbers?
Comment: only in agreement suffixes but these occur very rarely

Feature: Are person categories neutralized under some conditions?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Under negation, In a certain TAM context, Unclear whether the verb form counts as finite

Feature: Is there an opposition between three or more distance terms in the demonstrative system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The distinction is distance from speaker versus hearer

Feature: Is elevation morphologically marked in demonstratives?
Is the opposition visible-non-visible marked on demonstratives?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The demonstrative classifier system is the same as another classifier system, Demonstratives agree with what is treated as noun classes

Feature: Are there declensions (partly) determined by number of the noun?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are different forms for marking number depending on the noun class, There are different forms for marking number which seem to be phonologically conditioned, The markers are adjacentbut not treated as bound

Feature: Are there declensions (partly) determined by gender of the noun?
Are there nouns which are suppletive for number?
Can singular number be marked on the noun itself?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can dual number be marked on the noun itself?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Are there associative plurals?

Feature: Are there noun classes/genders?
Is sex a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Feature: Is shape a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Are there numeral classifiers?

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?

Feature: Is alienable/inalienable a relevant distinction?

Can possession be marked by a prefix?

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Comment:
Among inflectable verbs, vowel-initial verbs take person prefixes while stop-initial verbs only take the voicing feature of the person prefixes and merge it to their initial stop (which then becomes voiced). This could also be seen as a morpho-phonological process rather than conjugation classes. 
There is also the irregular verb 'to eat'.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, They are transitive versus intransitive verbs

Feature: Are there (several) verbs which can be used either transitively or intransitively with no morphological marking?
Comment: has to be checked
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are only very few examples are or restricted in some way

Feature: Is there transitivising morphology (include clitics)?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reflexive action?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reciprocal action?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there a copula for predicate nominals?

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Hard to distinguish from verb compounding, Limited to some verbs e.g. English 'go buy food'

Feature: Are there aspectual auxiliaries?
Comment: clause-final: baʔa 'already' --> completion

Feature: Are there tense auxiliaries?
Is verb compounding a regular process?

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?

Feature: Are there positional (classificatory) verbs?

Feature: Can negation be marked clause-finally?

Feature: Are verbal and non-verbal predicates marked by the same negator?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, A special negator or negative form of the verb is used for existential meanings, A special negator or negative form of the copula is used with nominal predicates, A special negator or negative form of the copula is used with predicative adjectives, Other negative forms but which are discounted by the clarifying comment

Comment: No case marking, therefore all participants have the same zero-marking.
